newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: Third World trade group wants talks with G-7.
newsitem.headline: Third World trade group wants talks with G-7.

text.p: A Third World group on trade and economic cooperation pressed on Tuesday for talks with the Group of Seven industrialised countries (G-7).
In a communique at the end of a three-day summit in Zimbabwe, the Group of 15 (G-15) said regular meetings between the two groups would enhance North-South economic cooperation.

"Over the years, the G-15 has made energetic and consistent attempts at establishing a useful interaction with the G-7," it said. "We remain committied to carrying out regular, constructive and fruitful dialogue with our developed country partners".
The G-7 comprises the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada.

The G-15 was formed in 1989 and has retained its name although its membership has expanded to 16 countries -- Algeria, Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Egypt, India, Indonesia, Jamaica, Malaysia, Mexico, Nigeria, Senegal, Peru, Venezuela, Yugoslavia and Zimbabwe.
